content: <xml>   <records>        <record>       <contributors>         <authors>           <author>Zakaria Belhachmi</author>           <author>Christophe Prudhomme</author>           <author>Murielle Torregrossa</author>           <author>Christophe Prudhomme</author>           <author>Zakaria Belhachmi</author>           <author>Murielle Torregrossa</author>           <author>Guillaume Doll\ufffd\ufffd</author>         </authors>       </contributors>       <titles>         <title>Diffuse optical tomography for tumour detection</title>         <secondary-title/>       </titles>       <doi>10.5281/zenodo.11641</doi>       <pages/>       <volume/>       <number/>       <keywords>         <keyword>Tomography</keyword>         <keyword>Optic</keyword>         <keyword>Image</keyword>         <keyword>Reconstruction</keyword>         <keyword>Time-Resolved</keyword>         <keyword>Feel++</keyword>         <keyword>feelpp</keyword>         <keyword>FEM</keyword>         <keyword>DOT</keyword>         <keyword>TR-DOT</keyword>       </keywords>       <dates>         <year>2014</year>         <pub-dates>           <date>2014-06-18</date>         </pub-dates>       </dates>       <abstract><p><em>Time-resolved diffuse optical tomography</em> aims to reconstruct images for internal parts of a body (diffusive objects owning one or several inclusions, small animals, ...) from its boundary measures.<br />     This poster gives an overview of the experimental setup created by the ICube/IMIS team and the mathematical model used for the reconstruction. Numerical results are obtained using FEEL++, a C++ library for finite element methods.</p></abstract>     </record>      </records> </xml>
